document.docAuthor: Ekins, Merrick, Erpenbeck, Dirk, Wörheide, Gert & Hooper, John N. A.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of lithistid sponge hiding within the Isabella mirabilis species complex (Porifera: Demospongiae: Tetractinellida) from seamounts of the Norfolk Ridge

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of lithistid sponge hiding within the Isabella mirabilis species complex (Porifera: Demospongiae: Tetractinellida) from seamounts of the Norfolk Ridge

Colour . Wine Dark purple/brown in ethanol.
Oscules . Numerous microscopic exhalant oscules 0.05–0.2 mm in diameter.
Texture . Hard, slightly compressible but brittle.
Surface ornamentation . Uneven and slightly hispid caused by oxeas protruding several millimetres above the surface.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1 . Specimens of
I. mirabilis ,
on the left, the Holotype MNHN DCL 3903 (QM G318560), and on the right G318751.

FIGURE 2. Preserved specimens of
I. mirabilis
. Back row, from left to right: G318751, G329916 and G329917. Middle row: G329919, G329920, G329921 and G329924. Front row: G329925, G329922 and G329923.

subSubSection.paragraph: Ectosomal skeleton . The ectosomal skeleton consists of an exterior skin like crust of microscleres with smooth dichotriaenes and occasionally triaenes perpendicular to the surface. The microscleres consist of abundant asymmetrical euasters like streptasters resembling jacks, and microxeas. The microxeas consist of smooth and microspinose curved oxeas that are predominantly centrotylote.

Megascleres . Desmas are slender tripodal dicranoclone as described previously (
Schlacher-Hoenlinger et al. 2005
). The desmas range in size from 339–766 – 1370
x 20–60
– 347 µm. Dichotriaenes with rounded and sharp rhabdome tips are extremely variable in shape resembling every shape from a promonaene, triaene, dichotriaenes , dichodichotriaene, trichotriaene to pentatriaene (see
Fig. 5
). Variability in dichotriaene shape has been noted in other lithistids such as
Reidispongia coerulea
Pisera & Lévi, 2002
. Triaenes are occasionally found, often resembling an immature dichotriaene. Oxeas are very long, thin and sharp originating in the choanosome and extending in bundles out to the exterior of the sponge. (Refer to
Table 1
for megasclere dimensions).

Microscleres . Centrotylote microacanthoxeas are very common, very rarely (< 0.5 %) with thorns, there are also microacanthoxeas lacking an obvious central swelling. Smooth microxeas also exist which may or may not also have a central swelling. These smooth microxeas have variable tips (See
Fig. 4
). The microscleres also consist of abundant symmetrical microspinose spirasters with long thin arms and symmetrical ‘Jacks’ microspinose streptasters with short thick arms. (Refer to
Table 1
for microsclere dimensions).

……continued on the next page Remarks. The holotype and other material examined of
I. mirabilis
differ from the original description (Schlacher- Hoenlinger et al. 2005 ), by the presence of smooth microxeas, and smooth centrotylote microxeas, the occasional presence of triaenes, and the presence of very long oxeas. In addition measurements of all the mega- and microscleres have found a larger range than initially reported. The variability and concept of this species are discussed in more detail in a comparative context, below.
